channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: America in the age of the envoy
item.description: A new emphasis in diplomacy isn’t all downside.

item.title: What I learned about North Korea’s nuclear paranoia in Pyongyang
item.description: Misreading threats in Pyongyang two decades ago preceded nuclear weapons. Now similar fears spread across Asia.

item.title: Southeast Asian manufacturing: No longer immune from geopolitics
item.description: The region’s industrial sector must adapt in a new climate of supply-chain weaponisation.

item.title: Ramaphosa Capitalizes on Trump’s Absence at G-20 Summit
item.description: But some experts warn that a lack of U.S. involvement weakens the bloc’s final declaration.

item.title: Who will win the trillion-dollar robotaxi race?
item.description: It’s Waymo complicated than it looks

item.title: Don’t Call This a ‘Peace Plan’
item.description: If the U.S.-Russia plan for Ukraine goes forward, Donald Trump will be remembered as the Neville Chamberlain of the 21st century.

item.title: Holiday 2025 Reading List
item.description: In the PS Book Recommendations newsletter – available for free to all registered Project Syndicate users – we highlight insightful, informative, or otherwise compelling books, written or recommended by PS contributors. This holiday season, we present a selection of recent works by PS contributors that you don’t want to miss.

item.title: The War Room newsletter: Altitude sickness, struggling jets and cold batteries
item.description: Shashank Joshi, our defence editor, visits the disputed border between Pakistan and China

item.title: How Africa Can Meet Its Green Industrialization Imperative
item.description: One upside to geopolitical fragmentation is that the rules and systems that have long constrained Africa’s development and industrial policies are being eroded. The continent’s governments must seize this opportunity to develop higher-value-added sectors that can simultaneously strengthen climate resilience.

item.title: More Americans are being put to death
item.description: How the Supreme Court ushered in a surge in executions

item.title: Brazil is embracing its African roots
item.description: It is the country that imported by far the largest number of African slaves

item.title: Europe’s Critical Raw Materials Strategy
item.description: With China dominating the global supply of rare-earth magnets and other critical materials, Europe is dangerously vulnerable to shortages and potential export controls. EU institutions, governments, and industry must act quickly to secure these supply chains and create buffers against future shocks.

item.title: The U.S.-Russia Plan Gives Trump a $300 Billion Signing Bonus
item.description: If Europe moves fast to seize Russian assets, it may be able to sink this bad deal.

item.title: Has Trump’s America Gone Rogue?
item.description: The Trump administration’s cavalier approach to the rule of law is the end of an era.

item.title: The Wrong Way to Peace in Ukraine
item.description: It was revealed last week that Russian President Vladimir Putin and US President Donald Trump have been secretly negotiating a settlement to the war in Ukraine. But this “peace” plan, if implemented, would encourage Russia to continue waging war in Europe, undermine the international order, and increase the risk of nuclear war.

item.title: China’s Communist Party wants positive energy only, please
item.description: But enforced online optimism is no remedy for economic gloom

item.title: The world proves thirstier than ever for energy
item.description: But the Trump administration is trying – and failing – to play a spoiler role while China focuses on the long game.

item.title: How the Trump-Xi Summit Led to a Blow up in China-Japan Ties
item.description: A tactical truce with the United States has redirected China’s coercive pressure toward Tokyo and across the Taiwan Strait.

item.title: How MAGA Hopes to Pervert Transatlanticism
item.description: Under US President Donald Trump's second administration, transatlanticism is being transformed from an internationalist project into a nationalist one. Not only is Trump's MAGA movement unapologetically nationalist, but it is eager to make common cause with Europeans who share its chauvinist view of politics.

item.title: India’s Fraught Push for Digital Decolonization
item.description: Will the dream of indigenous technology be co-opted for political control?

item.title: A Philippine Youth Climate Activist on a Deadly COP30
item.description: Performative ambition failed the Global South – again.

item.title: Why Ukraine Deserves to Survive
item.description: With a new US-Russia peace plan proposing what amounts to Ukraine's capitulation to its aggressor, a corruption investigation focusing on President Volodymyr Zelensky's inner circle would seem to be the last thing the country needs. But the opposite is true.

item.title: Kyrgyz Authorities Arrest Alleged Protest Plotters Ahead of Election
item.description: Once again, the Kyrgyz government has cried wolf as an election approached.

item.title: UN Declares Detention of Rohingya Leader Arbitrary
item.description: Dil Mohammed has been detained in Bangladesh since January 2023. The WGAD just ruled that his incarceration “lacks any legal basis and is thus arbitrary.”

item.title: Type 076 Warship Highlights PLA’s Shift Toward Unmanned Aerial Dominance
item.description: The integration of China’s drone technology with its new amphibious assault ships reflects its military modernization and shift in strategic focus.

item.title: Why India Will Not Extradite Sheikh Hasina
item.description: Dhaka has sent India a note verbale requesting the extradition of the former PM, who has been found guilty of crimes against humanity and sentenced to death.

item.title: Hongqi Bridge Collapse Is a Warning. China’s Leaders Should Listen.
item.description: Poor-quality construction continues to plague China because the incentives haven’t changed.

item.title: In Uzbekistan, Local Development Without Local Democracy
item.description: A new scheme to allocate funds for mahalla-level infrastructure is unlikely to cater to actual local needs.

item.title: Cover Story newsletter: Welcome to Anything Goes America
item.description: How we chose this week’s image

item.title: When Democrats Rebelled Against Their Own Leaders
item.description: Ralph Nader and the Watergate Babies challenged aging House chairmen.

item.title: The Inevitable Logic of a Japanese Nuclear Weapon
item.description: Rapid geopolitical change requires an urgent debate in Japan.

item.title: ASEAN Is No Longer Just a Talk Shop
item.description: The bloc is beginning to have some agency—as long as you don’t mention China.

item.title: America’s Toothless Sanctions on Russian Oil
The End of the Longest Peace?
item.description: One of history’s greatest achievements is under threat.

item.title: Chairman of Indonesia’s Largest Islamic Group Rejects Calls to Resign
item.description: Yahya Cholil Staquf, the chairman of Nahdlatul Ulama, is accused of inviting a pro-Israeli speaker to appear at an internal event in August.

item.title: To Vote or Not to Vote for Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami
item.description: Bangladeshis have not forgotten the Jamaat’s role in the horrific violence of 1971. But they want change, a shift away from corruption

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Defense Upgrade Cannot Rely on Foreign Donations Only
item.description: Its military modernization should be shaped by a coherent, long-term acquisition plan, rather than what external partners are willing to donate.

item.title: Trump’s Russia-Ukraine Peace Plan Is a Step Forward
item.description: For Europe, continued war is perhaps not entirely unwelcome.
